channel.title: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)
channel.description:
We'll i was reading topics about packet bots and that it was almost impossible to create on because the RSA Key always changes?
So i was thinking what if you could hook or reflect the Socket that the java client is using and the function to send the encrypted values (RSAEncrypt).. if you load your client then let it connect etc.. After that if you use the hooked or reflected function and the hooked or reflected socket.. you have no problems with the encoding?
This is just an idea.. please correct me if i am wrong somewhere =)

item.title: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“ownagesbot, post:63, topic:289324”][quote author=Killer-99-pkz link=topic=382478.msg2947636#msg2947636 date=1252286088]
i would still rsa encrypt because they will easily catch you
[/quote]… you are a complete moron. If you didn’t RSA encrypt, the server wouldn’t even have a fuckin’ clue what you’re trying to do…[/quote]dont bother anymore, im pretty sure hes banned by now

Read full topic

item.title: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:61, topic:289324”][quote author=oksuper_ link=topic=382478.msg2950032#msg2950032 date=1252445268]

BTW I rule that people who doesn’t know how the protocol works shouldn’t post about the protocol.

Then how would they learn about the protocol?

There’s a thing called the client. The protocol-related code is pretty extremely simple to understand. If you lack the intelligence to understand it, take a break and pass the 6th grade.
[/quote]

Not with the current obfuscation it isn’t, in fact it is pretty hard to reverse engineer. It is doable, but certainly not fun.[/quote]
It’s not meant to be fun. It is still simple.

Read full topic

item.title: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)
item.dc:creator: @light232 light232
item.description:
@light232 wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:57, topic:289324”][quote author=xeez` link=topic=382478.msg2948638#msg2948638 date=1252355134]
If the client invokes [tt]java.lang.Math.random()[/tt] for the cipher keys, then why can’t one simply replace them with statically built ones?
[/quote]

No, no they don’t. PLEASE shut the fuck up and don’t act like you have any clue as to what you’re talking about. Their ‘cipher keys’ are created via the ISAAC algorithm. Math.random() is used to generate the client’s session key. [br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 07, 2009, 09:26:10 pm[/size][hr]BTW I rule that people who doesn’t know how the protocol works shouldn’t post about the protocol.[/quote]
you will get a heart-attack, calm down

Read full topic

item.title: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)
item.dc:creator: @Ben Ben
item.description:
@Ben wrote:

Doesn’t have to be static (that would be a way of identification for jagex), all you need to do is store the randomly created ciphers.
Anyhow, there’s really not much to crack here - just copy the decryption algorithm from the client and you have what you need.

Or if this is a proxy bot, you already got the messages decrypted for you to work with.

Read full topic

item.title: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:52, topic:289324”][quote author=Killer-99-pkz link=topic=382478.msg2945659#msg2945659 date=1252198326]
inject the rs2 client and make it not rsa encrypt it and hook the keys, then encrypt it in the proxy part

EDIT: oh wups didint notice you want to use direct, your going to need to do alooot more work if you wanna do that…clicking positions, TONS of modifications each time they update…etc
[/quote]…read what frank_ said

the correct way would be to inject bytecode into applyrsa() (or whatever you call it) so it stores the seeds and your bot can access them via reflection or such[/quote]

No, if you want the session keys you’d inject code to pass them along inside the login method when both are received or generated.

Read full topic

item.title: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)
item.dc:creator: @Ben Ben
item.description:
@Ben wrote:

Surely it is not straightforward but the similarities do exist and this is do-able.
Methods will be optimized as time passes, and it is not applicable for Jagex to do more than changing IDs or positions within their protocol.

Read full topic
item.source: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)

item.title: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

They do change the packet IDs, but they also change the protocol, such as the order of the data in each packet. Making it extremely hard to update a bot.

Read full topic
item.source: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)

item.title: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)
item.dc:creator: @Ben Ben
item.description:
@Ben wrote:

This process can be automated by us too, if not fully then partially.
It won’t be very easy but after the project gets mature enough patterns will be found and it will be easier to understand their process of updating the protocol.

For example, they may change the packet IDs but they won’t change the attributes for the packets (I am not yet familiar with the protocol’s specifics).
This leaves a group of possible type of packets for a specific ID.

If the proxy (or packet) bot packet IDs identification process becomes a community project, with the right tools this problem is easy to solve.

For example you may use the client for identifying packet IDs, asking the user what he had just done when a packet is sent, or stopping the client’s graphics from updating, while asking to select from a list what had just happened when an unidentified packet has arrived.

Read full topic
item.source: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)

item.title: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Sure, that would work. But where is the advantage? You’ve not saved yourself the need for any automatic engineering of bytecode, and you’ve added in the fact that protocol changes screw your bot massively - for, afaict, no gain at all

Unless of course, this would just be an epeen/personal project, then yeah it’s great.

Read full topic
item.source: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)

item.title: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

A packet bot would be ideal, but it would be a pain to maintain updated :(. I think a “proxy-bot” would be the optimal solution as it requires no actual updating in order for the bot to survive. Of course, when I say a proxy bot, I mean all but a standalone one. Before launching, the bot could load the client’s bytecode and search for the current public key. Then, when starting the client, the bot could use Java’s Instrumentation API to transform the loaded bytecode on the fly. With this, it could replace the ciphers that are created in the login-block dynamically, with static ones that the bot is already aware of.

Of course, after injecting a packet, the server’s RNG would not be synced with the client’s. To fix this, the bot could have two ciphers; a server cipher and a client cipher. When a packet is received from the server, the client removes the stream cipher sent from the server and adds the “client” cipher. When a packet is sent from the client, the client removes the stream cipher and adds the “server” cipher.

Read full topic
item.source: Packet Bot Idea (With Hooking or Reflection)
